title: The 4 Best Ways to Clean White Shoes

steps.title: Mix dish soap into 1 c (240 ml) of warm water.
steps.content: Mix dish soap into 1 c (240 ml) of warm water. Any liquid dish soap will work for cleaning your shoes. Use about 1 teaspoon (4.9 ml) of soap so the water is sudsy but still clear. Stir the cleaning solution so it’s evenly mixed. Then, using a soft cloth or toothbrush, gently scrub the shoes with the mixture, working in circular motions. [1] X Research source Soap and water work best on all kinds of shoes, including canvas shoes, tennis shoes, and white leather . If you don’t want to use dish soap, you can substitute 1 ⁄ 2 cup (120 ml) of white vinegar. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub stains with a stiff-bristled toothbrush.
steps.content: Scrub stains with a stiff-bristled toothbrush . Dip the head of the toothbrush into the water so the bristles are wet. Work the bristles in small circular motions on the surface of your shoes, focusing on heavily stained areas. Use a slight amount of pressure to work the cleaning solution into the shoe’s fabric. [3] X Research source Keep the toothbrush you use to clean out of the bathroom to avoid any confusion.

steps.title: Clean the soles
steps.content: Clean the soles and rubber pieces with a magic eraser. Dip the magic eraser into your soapy water and wring it out. Wipe in short back and forth motions along parts of your shoes made of leather, rubber, or plastic. Keep working the eraser until all scuffs and stains are removed. [4] X Research source Magic erasers can be found in the cleaning section of your local department store.

steps.title: Pat excess water away with a towel.
steps.content: Pat excess water away with a towel. Use either a cloth or paper towel to pat the soapy water and dirt off of the shoe. Avoid wiping the towel across the shoe’s fabric since you could spread the dirt across the fabric again. [5] X Research source Don’t try to completely dry your shoes with the towel. Just lift off the excess cleaning solution from the surface.

steps.title: Let your shoes air dry.
steps.content: Let your shoes air dry. After you initially pat them with a towel, put them in a well-ventilated area in your home so they can dry completely. Leave them alone for at least 2-3 hours before wearing them again. [6] X Research source Clean your shoes at night so you can leave them to dry overnight.

steps.title: Dilute 1 part of bleach with 5 parts water.
steps.content: Dilute 1 part of bleach with 5 parts water. Work in a well-ventilated area in your home, and mix the bleach and water in a small container. Be careful not to use more bleach or else it could give your white shoes a yellow tinge. [7] X Research source Bleach works best for white fabric shoes. Wear nitrile gloves while working with bleach to prevent any skin irritation.

steps.title: Work a toothbrush in small circles to loosen stains.
steps.content: Work a toothbrush in small circles to loosen stains. Dip the toothbrush in your bleach solution and start scrubbing your shoes. Focus on soiled areas and deep stains, applying slight pressure to the fabric. You should notice the stains lift out of the fabric. [8] X Research source Start with your shoes’ fabric before moving onto harder surfaces, like the soles.

steps.title: Wipe the bleach solution off your shoes with a damp towel.
steps.content: Wipe the bleach solution off your shoes with a damp towel. Wet a soft microfiber towel in clean warm water and wring it out until it’s damp. Apply gentle pressure as you wipe the towel over your shoes. [9] X Research source You can also remove the insoles from your shoes and run your shoes under the faucet.

steps.title: Let the shoes dry in a well-ventilated area.
steps.content: Let the shoes dry in a well-ventilated area. Leave your shoes in the room to dry for at least 5-6 hours before you plan on wearing them again. Try to let them dry overnight if you can to dry completely. [10] X Research source Put a fan in front of your shoes to speed up the drying process.

steps.title: Mix baking soda, vinegar, and hot water into a paste.
steps.content: Mix baking soda, vinegar, and hot water into a paste. Stir 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of hot water, 1 tablespoon (15 ml) of white vinegar, and 1 tablespoon (14 g) of baking soda together in a bowl. Continue mixing the solution together until it forms a thick paste. The baking soda and vinegar will start to fizz and bubble as it reacts. [11] X Research source Baking soda works best if you’re trying to clean canvas , mesh , or fabric shoes. If your paste is runny, add an additional teaspoon (5 g) of baking soda.

steps.title: Work the baking soda paste into your shoes using a toothbrush.
steps.content: Work the baking soda paste into your shoes using a toothbrush. Dip the head of the toothbrush into your paste and brush it into the fabric of your shoes. Apply gentle pressure to the bristles so the fabric absorbs the paste. Cover all of the exterior surfaces of your shoes with the baking soda paste. [12] X Research source Rinse your toothbrush thoroughly when you’re finished so the paste doesn’t dry in the bristles.

steps.title: Let the paste dry onto the shoes for 3-4 hours.
steps.content: Let the paste dry onto the shoes for 3-4 hours. Set the shoes in direct sunlight so the paste can dry or harden. Leave them outside until you can scratch the dried paste with a fingernail. [13] X Research source If you can’t keep your shoes outside, put them near a sunny window or in a well-ventilated room.

steps.title: Clap your shoes together and use a dry brush to remove the dried paste.
steps.content: Clap your shoes together and use a dry brush to remove the dried paste. Hit the soles of your shoes together outside so the paste breaks apart and falls to the ground. If there’s any dried paste chunks leftover, scrape them off with a dry toothbrush until your shoes are clean again. [14] X Research source If you can’t work outside, lay down a sheet to catch the dried paste.

steps.title: Wipe your shoes with a damp cloth to get them wet.
steps.content: Wipe your shoes with a damp cloth to get them wet. Wet the end of a microfiber cloth or towel and gently wipe it across your shoes. Get your shoes slightly damp but not soaking wet so the toothpaste can foam up. Try using toothpaste on fabric, mesh, or sneakers.

steps.title: Rub a pea-sized dab of toothpaste into the shoes with a toothbrush.
steps.content: Rub a pea-sized dab of toothpaste into the shoes with a toothbrush. Put the dab of toothpaste directly onto your shoes where there are heavy stains. Spread the toothpaste thin so it coats the entire area before working your toothbrush in small circular motions. Work the toothpaste into the shoes’ fabric thoroughly before letting it set for 10 minutes. Make sure to use a non-gel toothpaste that’s white. Other colors may leave stains on your shoes.

steps.title: Wipe the toothpaste and dirt away with a wet cloth.
steps.content: Wipe the toothpaste and dirt away with a wet cloth. You can use the same wet cloth as before to wipe the toothpaste off of your shoes. Make sure to get all of the toothpaste off your shoes so it doesn’t leave any marks.

steps.title: Let your shoes air dry completely for 2-3 hours.
steps.content: Let your shoes air dry completely for 2-3 hours. Set your shoes in front of a fan or in a well-ventilated room. Leave the shoes to completely dry. Once they’re dry, your shoes should look a few shades lighter. Leave your shoes outside in the sun to speed up the drying process.
